poem_title: To the Right Honourable William Clayton, Esq (now Lord Sundon) on his being Elected Representative in Parliament for Westminster without Opposition.
author: Stephen Duck

lines.line_text: TO You, great Steward of the public Trust,
True to your King, and to your Country just!
No venal Bard his joyful Tribute brings,
Nor  sure can censure what he sings;
Since each impartial Tongue your Praise declares,
The Muse but echoes, what the Poet hears.

stanzas.stanza_text:
TO You, great Steward of the public Trust,
True to your King, and to your Country just!
No venal Bard his joyful Tribute brings,
Nor  sure can censure what he sings;
Since each impartial Tongue your Praise declares,
The Muse but echoes, what the Poet hears.

lines.line_text: SOME, by their Birth, to Senates lay their Claim,
Whose Folly shames the  which honours
But You, whose Merits mov'd the People's Voice,
Unanimous, to make so wise a Choice,
With solid Sense, and prudent Conduct shew,
You grace the Senate, not the Senate You.
Where, in the List of Patriots, could we find
A sounder  a sincerer
Or where a juster  to poise the Scale
Of  and  Weal?
Nor  you strive to sink, nor  extend;
Bigot to neither Side, to both a Friend.
So flow the Spirits thro' our vital Frame;
Nor yet this Member chill, nor that inflame.

stanzas.stanza_text:
SOME, by their Birth, to Senates lay their Claim,
Whose Folly shames the  which honours
But You, whose Merits mov'd the People's Voice,
Unanimous, to make so wise a Choice,
With solid Sense, and prudent Conduct shew,
You grace the Senate, not the Senate You.
Where, in the List of Patriots, could we find
A sounder  a sincerer
Or where a juster  to poise the Scale
Of  and  Weal?
Nor  you strive to sink, nor  extend;
Bigot to neither Side, to both a Friend.
So flow the Spirits thro' our vital Frame;
Nor yet this Member chill, nor that inflame.

lines.line_text: TRUE to your Principles, you never stray
From  tho' Int'rest lead the Way:
For  you still employ your Tongue;
And, rather than commit, you suffer Wrong.
When  Waves o'erflow'd the  Plain,
And  barter'd Honesty for Gain;
No Gain, no Place, nor Profit could controul
The stubborn Virtue of your steady Soul:
You firm to  and  stood,
Unfashionably just, and obstinately good.

stanzas.stanza_text:
TRUE to your Principles, you never stray
From  tho' Int'rest lead the Way:
For  you still employ your Tongue;
And, rather than commit, you suffer Wrong.
When  Waves o'erflow'd the  Plain,
And  barter'd Honesty for Gain;
No Gain, no Place, nor Profit could controul
The stubborn Virtue of your steady Soul:
You firm to  and  stood,
Unfashionably just, and obstinately good.

lines.line_text: BUT why should I in feeble Numbers tell
Those Virtues, which your Actions paint so well?
For all the Actions of your Life proclaim
A Subject's loyal Love, a Patriot's Fame.
Your Care to keep the People's Int'rest sure,
Your Zeal to guard the Prince's Crown secure,
Make Prince and People both espouse your ;
Witness their latest Choice, and loud ;
When crowded Streets with Acclamations rung,
And CLAYTON's Praises dwelt on ev'ry Tongue;
Parties themselves agreed your Worth to boast,
Or differ'd only, who should praise it most;
While tim'rous Candidates the  declin'd,
And, to your nobler Brow, the Palm resign'd:
So fly the Stars before the rising Sun;
And, from his brighter Beams withdraw their own.
